rename.to: [bug] "library 'app' not found" when building for any iOS simulator on macOS x86_64

body: I have the same problem, delete `arm64` from `VALID_ARCHS = "arm64 x86_64";` in this file `src-tauri/gen/apple/Stority.xcodeproj/project.pbxproj`, helps for development, but is not a solution.

Thanks, @uvarov-frontend. In fact, your patch is similar to mine, but you edit the files directly whereas I do it from the IDE.

Looks like when we're ready for an actual device and not the simulator, the hack consists of removing `x86_64` instead of `arm64`. ðŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸
I have the exact same problem now with my old Intel MacBook.
I have the exact same problem now with my Intel MacBook.

Hi,

here is how it works for me with an Intel MacBook ...

1. initialize iOS
```sh
pnpm tauri ios init
```
3. open the `src-tauri/gen/apple/project.yml` and change to iOS 17 and w/o arm64 architecture
```yaml
  deploymentTarget:
    iOS: 17.0
...
   VALID_ARCHS = x86_64;
```
3. initialize again
```sh
pnpm tauri ios init
```
6. start your app
```sh
pnpm tauri ios dev
```
 
## Idea
`pnpm tauri ios init` provides an option to select the architecture [intel | arm64]
 or
e.g. `pnpm tauri ios init --intel` to switch explicit

Also a documention about apple with intel would be great.

But what if you want to built for both in the CI and for Intel locally?
I have the exact same problem now with my Intel MacBook.

I also have the same problem, but I'm on M3. Notably the default tauri project for iOS only builds x86_64. Details below I'm running the following `npm create tauri-app@latest ` go into project dir `npm install` and then `npm run tauri ios init` where the CLI only complains about no code signing cert (yellow, warning) I then run `npm run tauri ios dev` and chooses **iPhone 16 (iOS 18.6) simulator** Tauri then complains about Xcode simulator SDK not beeing installed > Info Starting simulator iPhone 16 > Warn No code signing certificates found. You must add one and set the certificate development team ID on the `bundle > iOS > developmentTeam` config value or the `APPLE_DEVELOPMENT_TEAM` environment variable. To list the available certificates, run `tauri info`. > Building app... > Warn Xcode Simulator SDK 18.5 is not installed, please open Xcode > Warn To develop on physical phones you need the `--host` option (not required for Simulators). See the documentation for more information: https://v2.tauri.app/develop/#development-server > Info Opening Xcode However I think it is installed I then press build (Play-button) in Xcode The rust code is compiled. The build stops at "library 'app' not found" Chat GPT was helpful to analyze errors. The gist is that Clang is trying to link **libapp.a** from the ../src-tauri/gen/apple/Externals/arm64/debug folder . But it is only present in the ..../src-tauri/gen/apple/Externals/x86_64/debug folder.

Yeah getting some very weird behaviour here on an M1 device with iOS sim development after updating tauri, tauri cli, rust and Xcode to the latest versions.

iOS sim. dev is totally broken for me right now. Xcode version 16.4 lets the user download "iOS 18.5 + iOS 18.6 Simulator" which is a package combo. When I have that installed and run `tauri ios dev` it can't find the right Xcode simulator SDK, I get:

```
Debug [cargo_mobile2::apple::target] installed runtimes: 18.4, 18.6
Warn [tauri_cli::mobile::ios::dev] Xcode Simulator SDK 18.5 is not installed, please open Xcode
```

I have tried:
- deleting gen/apple and `tauri ios init`
- playing around with ARCHS and EXCLUDED_ARCHS in apple/project.yml
- uninstalling & reinstalling Xcode and the 18.5/18.6 sim
- deleting and re-creating the simulators
- installing iOS 18.4 Simulator
- explicitly running on the sim with `tauri ios dev "iPhone 16 18.6"`
- compiling directly with Xcode which I get `Command PhaseScriptExecution failed with a nonzero exit code` and can't get rid of it
-  setting the app deploymentTarget explicitly

My `tauri info`:
```

    - tauri-plugin-shell ðŸ¦€: 2.3.0
```

Ok I seemed to fix my issue: 
1. Went into Xcode, deleted all iOS sim/runtimes via Xcode->Settings->Components menu
2. Performed `xcodebuild -downloadPlatform iOS -buildVersion 18.5` via cli, which then finally gave me the iOS 18.5 simulator profiles in Xcode (they did not show before)
3. Then I could re-init tauri iOS and then run `tauri ios dev "iPhone 16"` and it worked after the second run

@FabianLars is there a reason why Tauri isn't working with the 18.5 SDK + 18.6 Simulator combo? This is a valid out-of-the-box Xcode component installation. This probably should be a separate issue to this thread? ``` Warn Xcode Simulator SDK 18.5 is not installed, please open Xcode ``` I can confirm that executing the below command resolves the issue: ``` xcodebuild -downloadPlatform iOS -buildVersion 18.5 ```

Tauri didn't support this because it really never was a valid config before 18.6 and it still doesn't support it because we forgot to update the cli's lockfile for 2.8

Edit: reference for the lockfile mention, it was fixed in https://github.com/tauri-apps/cargo-mobile2/pull/474

And yes, you're right. The comments in the last 2 weeks are essentially off-topic.

That's great @FabianLars. Good to know a fix is in place for this!
P.S. Thanks for letting me know about the lock file issue. I noticed that yesterday and assumed my local environment had got into a bad state.

issue.title: fix(apple): simulator build on Intel machines
